skill.name: tmux
skill.description: Manage tmux sessions for interactive background processes
skill.summary: Manage tmux sessions for interactive background processes
skill.author: Bind

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only metadata and documentation files. No executable scripts were found in the directory. The skill defines MCP tools for tmux session management but the actual implementation files referenced in skill.json are not present. No network calls, filesystem access beyond tmux sessions, or command execution capabilities were detected in the scanned files.

content.value_statement: Running background processes in terminals can be complex when you need persistent sessions that survive disconnections. This skill provides simple commands to create, manage, and monitor tmux sessions from your AI assistant.
actual_capabilities: Create new tmux sessions with custom commands and working directories
Send commands to running tmux sessions
Capture and read output from tmux session panes
Wait for specific output patterns before capturing
limitations: Requires tmux and bun to be installed on the system
Cannot manage sessions across different tmux servers
Session names must be unique or the operation will fail

use_cases.title: Database session management
use_cases.description: Run persistent database connections like psql or mysql in background sessions and run queries on demand

use_cases.title: Log monitoring workflows
use_cases.description: Tail log files continuously in tmux sessions and capture output to check for errors or patterns

use_cases.title: Interactive REPL sessions
use_cases.description: Maintain Python or R REPL sessions for data analysis work with persistent state between commands

prompt_templates.title: List sessions
prompt_templates.prompt: List all active tmux sessions using the tmux skill

prompt_templates.title: Create database session
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new tmux session called 'psql-dev' that runs 'psql -h localhost -U postgres mydb'

prompt_templates.title: Run query and capture
prompt_templates.prompt: Send the command 'SELECT COUNT(*) FROM users;' to the 'psql-dev' session, wait for the 'postgres=#' prompt, then capture the output

output_examples.input: Create a tmux session called 'python-work' that runs python3
output: To send commands: Use send-command to interact with the session

best_practices: Use descriptive session names with prefixes like 'psql-', 'logs-', or 'repl-' to organize multiple sessions
Always kill sessions when done to free system resources
Use the --wait option with capture-output to ensure commands complete before reading output
anti_patterns: Running long-lived processes without monitoring their output or status
Creating sessions with generic names like 'test' or 'session1' that cause conflicts
Forgetting to specify --workdir when sessions need to access specific project files

faq.question: What platforms support this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works on any system with tmux installed, including Linux and macOS. It requires the bun runtime.

faq.question: What are the resource limits?
faq.answer: Session count and output capture lines are limited by tmux configuration. Default capture returns 100 lines of scrollback.

faq.question: How does it integrate with AI tools?
faq.answer: The skill exposes MCP tools that AI assistants can call directly. Each command maps to a specific tmux operation.

faq.question: Is data stored or transmitted?
faq.answer: No. All data stays local on the machine running tmux. Sessions exist only in memory until explicitly killed.

faq.question: Why are sessions hanging?
faq.answer: Check if tmux is installed and running. Verify session names are correct. Ensure commands in sessions have finished before capturing output.

faq.question: How does it compare to screen?
faq.answer: Tmux offers more modern features like split panes, session cloning, and better scripting support than GNU Screen.
